executive_summary: Frozen pizza producers contended with challenging operating conditions over the past five years, as rising competition from pizzerias, changing consumer tastes and rising health consciousness have gradually reduced the growth in demand for processed or frozen foods. A boost in disposable income levels enabled more consumers to order takeout or delivery from pizzerias, reducing demand for frozen, store-bought pizzas. In response, frozen pizza producers have reformulated existing products to reduce excess sodium and preservatives while introducing new varieties made with organic or all-natural ingredients.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Economic Conditions During Covid-19 Benefited Lower-Cost, Frozen Foods Alternatives
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Frozen pizza producers endured significant volatility within their core markets over the past five years, as strengthening per capita disposable income and consistent competitive pressure from external industries created a variety of barriers to growth. Frozen pizzas are preferred during economic hardships, as consumers lack the fiscal flexibility to eat out or purchase pizza from a restaurant. Overall, revenue is expected to expand at a CAGR of 2.3% through the end of 2024 to an estimated $6.5 billion in 2024, despite a 0.3% dip in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Spike in Input Prices Influences Rate of Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During COVID-19, a significant shift in consumer habits bolstered producer revenue, as the impact of lockdowns and social distancing measures pushed consumers away from outdoor venues and encouraged buying frozen pizzas. Many producers have also expanded their product line to incorporate specialty frozen pizzas with different flavors and toppings, creating a diverse array of low-cost and delicious options for consumers during the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Swelling Emphasis on Healthy Eating Strengthens Push to Innovate Frozen Pizzas
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, consumers have shifted their propensity toward healthier food choices, as exemplified by a relatively stable healthy eating index over the past five years, allowing frozen pizza producers to invest in healthier frozen pizza alternatives. Major companies, like Nestle SA (Nestle), continue to invest significant capital into its iconic frozen pizza brand, DiGiorno, by providing design-a-pizza varieties geared toward health-conscious consumers who may look for healthier toppings on their frozen pizza.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Full Economic Recovery Poised to Dampen Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As economic conditions are poised to stabilize following a period of volatility during COVID-19 and higher prices amid inflationary pressures, frozen pizza producers will struggle to maintain consumer interest in their products. With disposable income poised to heighten and consumer confidence rebounding following the pandemic, downstream customers will have higher flexibility to pursue dine-out and restaurant options when looking for pizza, which will hamper operator growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stabilization of Input Prices is Set to Benefit Operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With frozen pizza producers in high demand for raw goods, like wheat, cheese and vegetables, to produce their pizzas, the expected slowdown in commodity prices following high inflation will benefit producers' growth prospects. Meager growth in the world price of wheat and slower growth rates in the prices of vegetables compared with the previous five years will provide respite for frozen pizza producers' operational costs while allowing them to invest more into healthier, higher-margin alternative pizzas.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ACCELERATION OF TECHNOLOGY WILL ENHANCE CONSUMERS' FOOD OPTIONS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As technological innovation picks up, consumers will have more options to order pizzas directly to their homes, which may benefit frozen pizza producers looking to diversify their outreach. The swelling adoption of online food processing delivery provides producers with a new demand niche. At the same time, the consistent push toward automated equipment within the pizza manufacturing process is set to streamline frozen pizza production.

industry_definition: Frozen pizza manufacturers produce flash-frozen pizzas, which are then securely packaged and distributed to a range of merchandisers, notably grocery wholesalers, supermarkets, convenience stores and other retail establishments. Consumers eventually buy these pizzas for ultimate consumption.
key_trends: An emphasis on quality enhances internal competition. Frozen food pizza producers that can craft quality pizzas with different tastes and styles will gain a competitive edge compared with other frozen pizza producers.

Expansion in online delivery services enhances external competition. As the proliferation of popular online food delivery services, like Uber Eats, expands, traditional frozen pizza producers will have a harder time securing customers.

A strong appetite for at-home eating strengthens frozen pizza demand. The shift among consumers to eat at home and avoid restaurant pizzas after the pandemic has enhanced frozen pizza's appeal among diverse customers.

Long-term uncertainty over commodity prices will dampen future growth prospects. Frozen pizza producers will continue to contend with shaky commodity prices, particularly as their propensity to diversify their product stream requires a higher input of raw goods.

Name recognition bolsters a company's control of the market. Prominent companies, like Nestle Sa (Nestle), can leverage larger revenue growth because of their prominent name recognition among a large customer base.

Strong product development boosts a company's ability to heighten market share. As companies continue to invest in newer, tastier and diversified frozen pizza flavors and options, they will be able to reach a larger customer base.

A drop in per capita wheat flour consumption sends a worrying signal for frozen pizza producers. If broader wheat consumption trends are downward, it highlights consumers' propensity for alternative foods with fewer carbohydrates.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue primarily through wholesalers and distributors of frozen pizzas; this mainly includes grocery wholesalers who acquire frozen pizza products directly from manufacturers and sell them to downstream grocery stores, supermarkets, convenience stores and broader retail channels.

The retail industry generates revenue through retailers, including large supermarket chains and convenience stores, who sell their products to the end-consumers. They range from classic frozen cheese pizza to specialty options.
This market segment generates revenue from alternative market streams, including direct-to-business services, which allow a client to purchase frozen pizzas directly from the producer.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Regular and Thin Crust with Classic Toppings
products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from selling regular and thin-crust frozen pizzas, which include standard bleached-wheat crust with classic toppings like pepperoni, mozzarella cheese or sausage.
This product segment generates revenue from selling specialty crust frozen pizzas, which have a variety of specialty toppings and premium customization options.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Deep Dish and Thick Crust Varieties
products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from selling deep dish and thick crust pizzas, offering a variety of flavors to cater to diverse customer preferences.

tier_1_suppliers: Frozen Pizza Production in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US
Dairy Product Production in the US
Frozen Food Production in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Frozen Food Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Pizza dough is made from wheat, so the amount of wheat Americans consume directly impacts demand for frozen pizza producers' products. As consumers become more health-conscious, many cut wheat and carbohydrates out of their diets, constraining demand for frozen pizza products. A dip in per capita wheat flour consumption can translate to lower revenue for frozen pizza producers.

business_locations.location_description: A crucial factor influencing establishment growth is their proximity to core commodity producers, including vegetable growers and dairy producers, with the Great Lakes housing a significant portion of these inputs. In states like Illinois, the prevalence of large population centers and corporate headquarters of companies like Nestle SA provides proximity to core customers and input producers for establishments.

The prevalence of various population hubs creates a wide range of opportunities for establishments in the Western region. These opportunities may include setting up new businesses, expanding existing products or exploring diverse marketplace potentials. In states like California, booming metropolitan centers and a well-established statewide infrastructure provide a streamlined process to access customers and deliver frozen pizzas efficiently.

As the Southeast continues to benefit from a more significant corporate presence, it generates opportunities for frozen pizza producers. These producers can capitalize on the budding market, potentially expanding and boosting profit for their business. In states like Florida, the prevalence of input production hubs of core commodities, coupled with booming metropolitan centers, creates a favorable environment for new establishments.

The Mid-Atlantic region benefits from a large-scale population presence that creates a diversified customer base for establishments. This region also enjoys a rich cultural diversity, enhancing the dynamic and varied demands of the market. In states like New York, large city centers like New York City generate significant local demand for frozen pizza producers. This high demand stems from the city's dense population and fast-paced, convenience-driven lifestyle.

Although the Plains lacks a significant population presence, its spread-out geographic conditions and a notable concentration of core commodity input producers benefit frozen pizza producers. These establishments take advantage of local agricultural resources, resulting in cost-efficient bulk purchases and transportation, enhancing their profit. In states like Minnesota, the prevalence of processed meat and flour producers and large distances between customers create a unique demand for frozen pizza producers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Most regulatory oversight comes from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which protects public health by promptly ensuring that safe and effective products reach the market. The FDA governs frozen pizza producers via the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FD&C) and the Fair Packaging and Labeling Act. The FDA also instituted the Food Ingredient

Frozen pizza producers face significant environmental regulations because they use machinery and processing facilities. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and state governments enforce environmental issues about frozen pizza producers. Federal environmental laws and statutes, like the Clean Water Act (CWA), Clean Air Act, Pollution Prevention Act (PPA) and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, changed how processing facilities handle products and dispose of waste by implementing permit requirements on frozen pizza producers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Guidelines
regulations_points.regulation_description: OSHA is a federal agency responsible for enforcing worker safety and health. Under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Congress created OSHA to set and regulate standards for safe and healthy working conditions for men and women. Within section 1910, OSHA lists general regulations relevant for frozen pizza producers, including guidance for the construction of work environments, fire protection, monitoring noise levels, hazardous material storage and handling and disposal of waste.

To ensure worker safety and minimize the spread of COVID-19, frozen food producers implemented various safety measures to protect workers' safety. These regulations include mask mandates, social distancing measures and local lockdowns during the pandemic. Most of these measures have been removed as the COVID-19 vaccine continues to be rolled out.

basis_points.basis_description: Frozen food pizza producers that can craft quality pizzas with different tastes and styles will gain a competitive edge compared with other frozen pizza producers.

basis_points.basis_title: Expansion in online delivery services enhances external competition
basis_points.basis_description: As the proliferation of popular online food delivery services, like Uber Eats, expands, traditional frozen pizza producers will have a harder time securing customers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High Operational Costs Discourage Large-Scale Expansion
concentration_points.concentration_description: Frozen pizza producers endure significant operational prices following COVID-19, as high commodity prices and labor costs have tightened their overall profit margin. This has forced many frozen pizza manufacturers to reevaluate their supply chains, production methods and pricing strategies. Larger frozen pizza producers continue to focus on improvising their product line to gain a competitive edge, with expansion limited to the acquisition of input producers to lower production costs.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Growth in Regional Flavors Encourages Localization Among Producers
concentration_points.concentration_description: As individual regions continue to garner interest in specific pizza flavors, many frozen pizza producers are encouraged to stay small to secure a growing customer niche. By targeting local customers and wholesale distributors, smaller frozen pizza producers face an encouraging landscape and create an expanding demand niche for local producers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Swelling Inflationary Pressures Exacerbate Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A significant chunk of frozen pizza producers' expenses continues to be derived from purchases of raw goods and commodities, including flour, water, yeast, salt, sugar, dairy products and assorted vegetables and meat. As inflationary pressures have strengthened recently, many commodity prices have spiked, as exemplified by the spike in vegetable prices, contributing to growing purchase costs for frozen pizza producers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Steady Reliance on Raw Labor Bolsters Wage Expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many frozen pizza producers continue to rely heavily on physical labor, using human hands, to ensure adequate and consistent production of frozen pizzas.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: ROBUST DEVELOPMENT OF PRODUCTION TECHNOLOGY BOLSTERS ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some other costs accrued by frozen pizza producers focus on the adequate functioning of the pizza production facilities, with administrative, legal and insurance costs being a significant portion of those expenditures. In recent years, the expansion in automated equipment has bolstered producers' investment in research and development (R&D) to improve the efficiency of the production process.

volatility_points.volatility_title: HIGH COMMODITY PRICE VOLATILITY ENHANCES UNCERTAINTY SURROUNDING OPERATOR REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Although economic conditions improved following COVID-19, the prevalent inflation problem has heightened costs for core input products, including cheese and vegetables. These price hikes have led to a contraction in profit for frozen pizza producers over the past five years. Surging purchase costs linked to production materials and logistics are limiting frozen pizza producers' capacity to maintain steady revenue growth, thereby exacerbating the underlying volatility in the broader market.

volatility_points.volatility_title: EVOLVING CONSUMER TASTES INFLUENCE THE STABILITY OF TRADITIONAL REVENUE STREAMS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Rapidly evolving consumer tastes toward healthier or gourmet options may significantly destabilize traditional revenue streams that frozen pizza producers rely heavily on for financial stability. By gauging consumers' propensity to eat different flavors and tastes, revenue volatility can be managed more effectively, particularly among larger companies using economies of scale to procure the necessary goods in demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The implementation of automated equipment improves production efficiency
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: By incorporating automated equipment at frozen pizza production facilities, operators can enhance the production process and meet larger-scale demand from wholesalers and retailers, thereby increasing efficiency and ensuring a continuous supply of products to the market. Automated machinery that can produce and store a larger quantity of frozen pizzas, particularly those with diverse toppings, can offer a lower operating expenditure for frozen pizza producers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Continued acceleration of flash freezing techniques boosts life span of frozen pizzas
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Frozen pizza producers continue to upgrade their flash freeze technology, pushing boundaries in the specific area of pizza production and innovating the broader freezing technologies impacting the entire food industry. The implementation of cryogenic freezing reduces operating costs and boosts freezing efficiency, significantly enhancing the taste and extending the life span of frozen pizza, revolutionizing the industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Major players in the industry include, Nestle SA and General Mills Inc., which produce a variety of food products, including frozen pizza and various other goods.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: Producers maintain a competitive edge by developing new flavors and products in response to changes in consumer preferences. For example, as consumers are becoming more health conscious, companies have begun to develop frozen pizza with cauliflower crust.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators are consistently investing in research and development in order to reformulate existing products to be healthier, as well as developing new product lines.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Frozen pizza producers have experienced volatile input prices. This harms the predictability of future profits and can alter business operations.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Companies involved in food production often invest in acquiring patents for new products or technologies in order to keep their competitive edge over competitors.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies in the industry have incorporated automation into the production process, which the goal of reducing wages in the long run. However, as the technology is still being incorporated wages have yet to fall as a result of the implementation of this technology.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Operators are not impacted by international tariffs. Trade only accounts for a negligible portion of revenue.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: In 2016, the Federal Drug Association announced new packaging requirements that is estimated to cost the industry about $2.0 billion, dampening profit margins.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Most operators in the frozen food production industry sell their goods to large wholesalers or directly to retail locations, who have the budgets and ability to pay on time.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the world price of wheat and the price of milk negatively affects profit margins as these inputs become more costly.

FAQs.question: Do you manufacture a wide variety of products? What new products are you currently developing?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies differentiate their frozen pizzas to maintain market share and increase revenue.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How quickly can you modify your products to suit market trends?
FAQs.answer: Companies that are able to anticipate and respond to changes in consumer preferences in a timely manner will be successful.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? How do you mitigate volatility in input costs?
FAQs.answer: Most companies have reliable contracts with suppliers for key inputs like flour, vegetables and meat, to reduce supply volatility considerably. Additionally, guaranteed supplies at fixed prices minimize supply costs and aid production planning.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by fluctuations in the healthy eating index? How can you promote the health benefits of your products?
FAQs.answer: Americans' personal perspective regarding pizza's nutritional value sways demand; since most Americans do not consider pizza to be a particularly healthy meal, rising health consciousness reduces demand for operators' products.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? Do you sell price-premium products?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have more money to spend, the more products they demand. However, frozen pizza represents a lower-priced alternative to eating pizza from food service establishments so consumers buy more operator goods when disposable income falls.

FAQs.question: What are the effects on your operation when the price of wheat increases? Do you have fixed, long-term supply contracts with wheat suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Wheat, which is used to make dough, is the most important input in the production of pizza. When the price of wheat rises, operating costs also increase, cutting into profit.
